summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of North Carolina yesterday entered a final judgment against two individuals charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Charlotte, North Carolina, alleges that Carol Folt, in her official capacity as Chancellor of the University of Carolina-Chapel Hill, and Josh Stein, in his capacity as Attorney General, violated Section 10(b) ofÂ The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's order, Folt and Stein violated Section 17 (a) and (c) of Section 10 of the Exchange Act and Rule 12(b)(1) thereunder and Section 13(a)(2) of Exchange Act Rule 12b-1.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of the final judgment, which permanently enjoins them from violating the federal securities laws and orders them to pay disgorgement of $5,000, prejudgment interest of $1,038, and a civil penalty of $500,000.  In a parallel action, the U.N. Office of Inspector General today announced that it has issued an order suspending the conduct of the two individuals and ordering them to return to their jobs and to pay civil penalties of $25,000 each.  On May 24, 2018, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Folt for her participation in this conduct, and against Stein for his participation in the same conduct alleged in the SEC complaint.  To learn more about undercover investigations of public and private facilities, see http://www.sec.gov/investigations/animal-cruelty-related-cases.html.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01221 (January 24, 2019).  The complaint also names as a defendant PETA, ALDF, and PETA as relief defendants for the purpose of recovering their allegedly ill-gotten gains from the alleged misconduct.   The court's order also prohibits Folt from participating in or participating in any undercover investigation of public or private facilities for purposes of standing to assert a First Amendment challenge to the Act.  PETA and ALDF have agreed to settle the case against them by consenting to a permanent injunction against future violations of the federal anti-fraud laws, and to the appointment of a receiver to determine whether to proceed with the investigation.  Among other things, the court granted the defendants' motion for a temporary restraining order against further violations, and ordered Folt to disgorge her allegedly ill
